body: Where ever there is a DB change the pattern is in use. The plain switch is used where it is db readonly.
Can't currently check the output of Apache Build Jenkins as it returns 404. Wanted to double check the UNSTABLE state. Holding on for now..

@remibergsma https://builds.apache.org is available, maybe https://builds.apache.org/job/cloudstack-pull-requests/1001/ got removed from the server as it was 7days old. In that case it will always return 404.

The updateBuilder will check if the DAO has changed based on the set_() methods. When it can't resolve one, it won't update. After learning this I changed the set_() method names to reflect the names of the variable fields.
LGTM

LGTM

Keep them coming!
Tested it in a new environment. The nics are correctly put in the db again.
@remibergsma @karuturi Please review!
Although I think the code is good and I want to give a LGTM, I'm just not 100% sure about this one.

LGTM. lets wait for travis and other jenkins verifications.

In future, can you club all refactoring work in a branch and merge them together? That way, we can test it once(giving bigger time window for everyone to verofy) and merge
Also, I think this refactoring is a candidate for 4.7. We are already close to RC on 4.6(once 4.5.2 is done) and cannot afford regressions at this stage.

@DaanHoogland in addition to failing to convey the intention of the action, the open then close pattern is incredibly expensive due to rapid, unnecessary churn on the connection pool.  Please see my response above for my thoughts on how we can improve it and avoid the nasty side effects the `TransactionLegacy` imposes.
LGTM
@karuturi I came to that conclusion in the previous pr. I will stack all refactoring work in a branch. And send a PR when done.

You mention replacing deployDestination with something serializable but I don't see it,

Why is a simple (de)serialization test not usefull? it will catch some things won't it?
A > serialize > desrialize > B
assertEquals(A,B);

btw removal if primitive types in serializable classes is something we do need.
@borisroman Thanks! I'll run some tests later tonight. Travis is green, didn't see an Apache build reporting results (yet?).

@borisroman I suggest you close this PR and do all the refactor work in a separate branch, as discussed. Thanks!

Hi @DaanHoogland, after we opened the Jira Ticket, someone ended up assigning it to us!? So, we decided to take a lead and analyze the impact that the proposed changes may cause. It turns out that most of the classes of that hierarchic are singletons, therefore it would not have an impact on memory consumption. The result of the analysis is the following:

@jburwell  @DaanHoogland There is a underlying connection pool to save on expensive db connection operations. Moreover this cost should be similar to opening and closing transactions without switching DB.
I think we should divide the DB transaction issue into two:
1. The expense of the operation and how it can be avoided. My initial thoughts are that this is trivial and non issue.
2. The way a DB switch is affected, is there a better pattern ?
@kishankavala @DaanHoogland Can you please review it?
Merging as 2 LGTMs

@remibergsma : i have added details to the bug . Copy pasting for your reference 
To have Active FTP working in isolated networks VRs need the have the following modules loaded (In order to map the FTP Data and FTP CMD to the same frontend IP):

```
modprobe nf_conntrack_ftp
modprobe nf_nat_ftp
```

in some versions of Cloudstack we noted that these modules are not loaded on CS Routers by default  . So this test case is for verifying that these modules are loaded by default in VR and if not report an error

@DaanHoogland I have verified using the simulator based on the repro steps mentioned in the bug. I found some issues in the simulator while testing this issue end-to-end, will push the simulator fixes as a separate PR.

Also I had done a (de)serialization test for VmWorkMigrateForScale. But I don't want to have it as unit test unless I see a valid justification (or some better way to test it).
@karuturi @wilderrodrigues I just created a ticket for it. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CLOUDSTACK-8761
LGTM -> Deployed on Centos7 started 2 systemvms, 1 router and 1 guest vm without libvirt errors.

I would like to see two unit tests for checkForKeyByPublicKey. The succes and the failure cases. I am not sure if this check shows a very good pattern but that is out of scope for this PR. Other then unit tests missing, LGTM.

@kishankavala a trivial test is better then none. for better tests, a jira ticket can be created and comments in the test class can be added.

that said LGTM

Might not be related as this is the first time I try the script, but I'm getting this:
eriweb@eriweb:~/git/cloudstack/tools/git master$ git pr 735 --force
WARNING: You used --force to merge a PR with non-clean merge state 'unstable'.
ERROR: We couldn't find a git remote pointing to 'apache/cloudstack.git' to merge the PR from.
INFO: Current remotes:
origin  git@github.com:apache/cloudstack (fetch)
origin  git@github.com:apache/cloudstack (push)

Seems to be because i used the git@github.com (which lacks the .git suffix), rather than the https form. Should be an easy fix (probably just drop the .git while greping)?
On the other side, if you just drop the '.git' suffix, you risk matching things like 'cloudstack-docs-rn' while you really mean 'cloudstack'
